segment.source: Configure Multiple Hard Drives
segment.target: Configure Multiple Hard Drives

segment.source: Configure Multiple Hard Drives
segment.target: Configure Multiple Hard Drives

segment.source: Configure Multiple Hard Drives
segment.target: Configure Multiple Hard Drives

segment.source: If you are deploying Windows to a computer that has multiple hard drives, you can verify that the image is applied to a specific hard drive by using hardware-specific identifiers such as the location path or the hardware interrupt value.
segment.target: If you are deploying Windows to a computer that has multiple hard drives, you can verify that the image is applied to a specific hard drive by using hardware-specific identifiers such as the location path or the hardware interrupt value.

segment.source: The location path is a string that specifies the physical location that each drive is connected to the computer, for example: .
segment.target: The location path is a string that specifies the physical location that each drive is connected to the computer, for example: .

segment.source: When manufacturing a computer, use a consistent physical location when connecting your drives, and then use the location path string to identify each hard drive.
segment.target: When manufacturing a computer, use a consistent physical location when connecting your drives, and then use the location path string to identify each hard drive.

segment.source: For BIOS-based computers or a computer that is running Virtual Disk Service (VDS), you can use the SELECT DISK=SYSTEM and SELECT DISK=NEXT commands to select the appropriate hard drive.
segment.target: For BIOS-based computers or a computer that is running Virtual Disk Service (VDS), you can use the SELECT DISK=SYSTEM and SELECT DISK=NEXT commands to select the appropriate hard drive.

segment.target: In this topic:

segment.target: Identifying a Drive Location Path

segment.source: Identifying a Disk Location Path
segment.target: Identifying a Disk Location Path

segment.source: Use the DiskPart commands: list disk and select disk disk number (Example: select disk 1) to navigate between the drives on your computer.
segment.target: Use the DiskPart commands: list disk and select disk disk number (Example: select disk 1) to navigate between the drives on your computer.

segment.source: To show the location path of a selected drive, use the DiskPart command .
segment.target: To show the location path of a selected drive, use the DiskPart command .

segment.source: In the following example, the location path of the selected drive is PCIROOT(0)PCI(0100)ATA(C00T00L00).
segment.target: In the following example, the location path of the selected drive is PCIROOT(0)PCI(0100)ATA(C00T00L00).

segment.source: Selecting Drives
segment.target: Selecting Drives

segment.source: Selecting the System Drive
segment.target: Selecting the System Drive

segment.source: BIOS-based computers: Use the command SELECT DISK=SYSTEM to select the default system drive.
segment.target: BIOS-based computers: Use the command SELECT DISK=SYSTEM to select the default system drive.

segment.source: This command selects the drive that has an interrupt 13h value of 80h.
segment.target: This command selects the drive that has an interrupt 13h value of 80h.

segment.source: If the value 80h is assigned to a USB flash drive, this command selects a hard drive that has a value of 81h.
segment.target: If the value 80h is assigned to a USB flash drive, this command selects a hard drive that has a value of 81h.

segment.source: For more information, visit the following Microsoft Developer Network (MSDN) website:
segment.target: For more information, visit the following Microsoft Developer Network (MSDN) website:

segment.source: Converting Drive Letters to MS-DOS INT 13H Disk Drive Numbers
segment.target: Converting Drive Letters to MS-DOS INT 13H Disk Drive Numbers

segment.source: UEFI-based computers: To select a drive, use the DiskPart command SELECT DISK=location path.
segment.target: UEFI-based computers: To select a drive, use the DiskPart command SELECT DISK=location path.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Do not use the SELECT DISK=SYSTEM command or the GetSystemDiskNTPath API on Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI)-based computers to select the system drive.
segment.target: Do not use the SELECT DISK=SYSTEM command or the GetSystemDiskNTPath API on Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI)-based computers to select the system drive.

segment.source: The SELECT DISK=SYSTEM command and the GetSystemDiskNTPath API identify the drive that the operating system was booted from as the system drive.
segment.target: The SELECT DISK=SYSTEM command and the GetSystemDiskNTPath API identify the drive that the operating system was booted from as the system drive.

segment.source: If you boot from Windows® PE, this command selects the Windows PE drive as the system drive.
segment.target: If you boot from Windows® PE, this command selects the Windows PE drive as the system drive.

segment.source: If you boot from a system that has multiple drives that include an EFI system partition (ESP), this command may select the wrong drive.
segment.target: If you boot from a system that has multiple drives that include an EFI system partition (ESP), this command may select the wrong drive.

segment.source: Selecting Non-System Drives
segment.target: Selecting Non-System Drives

segment.source: Select the drive by location path.
segment.target: Select the drive by location path.

segment.source: To select a drive, use the DiskPart command SELECT DISK=location path, where location path is the location path of your drive.
segment.target: To select a drive, use the DiskPart command SELECT DISK=location path, where location path is the location path of your drive.

segment.source: This command helps specify a drive by location.
segment.target: This command helps specify a drive by location.

segment.source: Example:
segment.target: Example:

segment.source: Select the drive by using the "NEXT" drive.
segment.target: Select the drive by using the "NEXT" drive.

segment.source: Use the DiskPart command SELECT DISK=NEXT.
segment.target: Use the DiskPart command SELECT DISK=NEXT.

segment.source: This command helps specify any remaining hard drives, regardless of location.
segment.target: This command helps specify any remaining hard drives, regardless of location.

segment.source: To select more drives, repeat the SELECT DISK=NEXT command to select each drive in order.
segment.target: To select more drives, repeat the SELECT DISK=NEXT command to select each drive in order.

segment.source: If there are no more drives to select, DiskPart returns an error.
segment.target: If there are no more drives to select, DiskPart returns an error.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The computer maintains the context for the SELECT DISK=NEXT command as long as DiskPart continues running.
segment.target: The computer maintains the context for the SELECT DISK=NEXT command as long as DiskPart continues running.

segment.source: If DISKPART exits, the computer loses this context.
segment.target: If DISKPART exits, the computer loses this context.

segment.source: Identifying the System Drive After a Reboot
segment.target: Identifying the System Drive After a Reboot

segment.source: After you reboot, drive lettering may change.
segment.target: After you reboot, drive lettering may change.

segment.source: You can use the following example script to select the system drive and then reassign letters to the ESP, recovery, and Windows partitions.
segment.target: You can use the following example script to select the system drive and then reassign letters to the ESP, recovery, and Windows partitions.

segment.source: Formatting Non-System Drives
segment.target: Formatting Non-System Drives

segment.source: This example script selects the system drive and then skips past the drive without modifying the contents of the drive.
segment.target: This example script selects the system drive and then skips past the drive without modifying the contents of the drive.

segment.source: The script then selects two non-system drives and creates a single, formatted, empty partition on each drive.
segment.target: The script then selects two non-system drives and creates a single, formatted, empty partition on each drive.

segment.source: The partitions do not receive an image, so it is not necessary to specifically identify them.
segment.target: The partitions do not receive an image, so it is not necessary to specifically identify them.
